headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Foxwoods Team Declines to Bid for Casino License in Catskills
summary: Foxwoods Resort Casino and Muss Development dropped plans to bid for a casino license in the Catskills because of potential competition in Orange County, according to a person familiar with their plans.

headline: Grant to Help Turn City Schools Into Services Hubs
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio's administration is taking a first step toward meeting a campaign pledge to turn at least 100 schools into community hubs that link families to services such as health clinics, job training and parenting workshops.

headline: New Jersey Chief Justice Advances
summary: A Senate committee signed off on the renomination of New Jersey Chief Justice Stuart Rabner, but national conservative groups continued to attack Gov. Chris Christie for his support of the Democratic justice.

headline: Budget Talks Tackle NYPD
summary: Council members are continuing to push for an increase in the department's head count as negotiations intensify in advance of the start of the city's fiscal year on July 1.

headline: Heard on the Field
summary: The Giants announced the signing of third-round pick Jay Bromley, meaning their entire draft class is under contract. Meanwhile, Las Vegas isn't more sold on the Rangers but bettors are taking notice, and the Mets get hammered by the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: Familiar Face Emerges in LICH Saga
summary: A tentative deal for the sale of Long Island College Hospital could signal victory for a Brooklyn developer that once looked poised to win the property easily and instead ended up in a six-month political fight.

headline: Mitsubishi Heavy Seeks More Global Sway
summary: Mitsubishi Heavy is looking to a possible joint venture with France's Alstom to expand the global reach of the Japanese firm's power-plant business.

headline: House Call for Historic Library
summary: The Hamptons are in a constant state of construction. With this in mind, supporters of the John Jermain Memorial Library, hosted a benefit at the home of Michael Graff and his wife, Carol Ostrow. Both the library and the home are undergoing renovations.

headline: Tracy Morgan Upgraded to Fair
summary: The condition of hospitalized comedian and actor Tracy Morgan was upgraded to fair from critical, his publicist Lewis Kay said Monday night.

headline: Flowers Fuel Fatal Newark House Blaze
summary: The house fire that killed an 11-year-old boy and five family members on Sunday was caused by a single heat source outside the home and was accelerated by decorative plastic flowers, authorities said.

headline: The Big Stars of Experimental Theater
summary: Mikhail Baryshnikov and Willem Dafoe in Robert Wilson 'The Old Woman' at BAM; Nannerl Mozart gets her due and more in this week's On Stage.

headline: Fracking Cases Echo Past Gas Boom
summary: The fate of two fracking lawsuits before New York's highest court hinges on 1981 legislation passed in an era with parallels to today, as new drilling technology fueled a gas-production boom.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of June 17, 2014

headline: Re-elected Colombian President Needs to Sell His Peace Plan
summary: Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos has won re-election, though the formidable test he overcame from hawkish opponent Oscar Iván Zuluaga underscores the deep challenge he faces to unite Colombians behind his signature peace process with Marxist rebels.

headline: Being N.Y.'s Second Team Costs the Mets
summary: Emory University study says Mets are second-worst in 'fan equity.'

headline: After the Biggest Win of His Life, Algieri Plots a New Future
summary: Before Saturday, Chris Algieri was a lightly regarded junior welterweight and a big underdog against WBO champion Ruslan Provodnikov. Now he's a world champion. What's next? For one, he can pay off his student loans.

headline: The Yankees' Adulterous Glove Story
summary: In the baseball world, where a player's relationship with his mitt is exclusive and long-term, sharing a glove is frowned upon. But the Yankees' ersatz first basemen don't care: They all use Kelly Johnson's first-base mitt.

headline: N.J. Expands Police Use of Heroin Antidote
summary: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie is expanding the use of a heroin antidote to both 900 state police officers and local law-enforcement offices across the state's 21 counties.

headline: Will Gwynn's Death Curb Use of Dip?
summary: The Hall of Famer, who died Monday at age 54, blamed smokeless tobacco for his cancer. But it still has a hold on the game, including several Mets. They know they shouldn't use the stuff, but quitting is hard.

headline: Naloxone Gives a Mother Back Her Son, but Can't Cure Addiction
summary: Peter Ruhry got what many other drug abusers never get: a second chance. He overdosed on heroin, but a shot of naloxone, an antidote, saved his life. Eighteen months later, though, he died of another overdose. Today, his mother advocates for the widespread use of naloxone.

headline: Photos of the Day: June 16
summary: In photos selected by Wall Street Journal editors Monday, a commuter faces a dust storm in India, Portugal's Pepe head butts a German opponent in the World Cup, rescuers work at the site of a factory collapse in China, and more.

headline: What's the Matter With Mexico?
summary: When Mexico faces Brazil in the World Cup, don't expect any close comparisons. Host Brazil has won the coveted prize five times. Mexico has yet to make it past the final eight.

headline: So Many Celiac Cases, So Few Diagnoses
summary: The Seidenbergs made a $16 million gift to NewYork-Presbyterian Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital because their grandchildren were diagnosed with celiac disease a few years ago.

headline: At 56, Brooklyn Artist Finally Gets His First New York Show
summary: The artist Steve Keene has had his work exhibited around the world in the past two decades, but only now is he getting his first formal exhibition in New York City.

headline: Allergan's Bitter Pill for Morgan Stanley
summary: Allergan, which is fending off a $53 billion takeover bid by Valeant, released emails sent by senior Morgan Stanley bankers appearing to denigrate Valeant and its business strategy.

headline: FDA to Increase Calls for More Fish Consumption
summary: The Food and Drug Administration says pregnant women and nursing mothers should include more seafood in their diets because the health benefits outweigh the risk that it might contain mercury.

headline: Medical Pot Debate Turns To Smoking
summary: The debate over legalizing medicinal marijuana on Monday turned to a new issue as opponents and advocates argued over whether patients should be allowed to smoke the drug when it is prescribed.

headline: A Steakhouse True to Its Roots
summary: For diners craving the steakhouse experience at lunchtime, Gallaghers, the 87-year-old Theater District restaurant which reopened this winter and started serving lunch in April, delivers the goods.

headline: Steel Dynamics Sees Earnings Improving This Quarter
summary: Steelmaker and metal recycler Steel Dynamics it expects higher per-share earnings for the current quarter than the year-ago period, citing a pickup in residential construction.

headline: A Plan to Save Iraq From ISIS and Iran
summary: Baghdad can be protected with American help and a counteroffensive launched to retake captured territory.

headline: The Pace of Obama's Disasters
summary: Bergdahl one week. Then Ukraine. Now Iraq.  What could be next?

headline: The Democrats Every Republican Should Quote
summary: Former officials and allies are getting worried about Obama's priorities, and willing to say so.

headline: Putin Has Exposed Europe's Cracks
summary: Poland's friends have gone missing as Russia threatens NATO's Eastern flank.

headline: Bill Clinton, Mark Sanford and Other Infamous Apologizers
summary: The typical public apology purports to be an expression of regret and self-reproach, but in fact is meant to defend and justify.

headline: Colombia's Peace Gamble
summary: Santos wins re-election but now must deal with the FARC.

headline: Kindred Offers $534 Million Bid for Gentiva
summary: The health care company draws up new takeover offer for $534 million in cash after receiving a rejection last month

headline: The Next Afghan President
summary: Sectarian failure in Iraq offers a lesson in what to avoid.

headline: Tehran's French Bankers
summary: A big fine against BNP Paribas may be deserved.

headline: Bring Highway Funding Up to Speed
summary: Fuel taxes give electric cars a free ride. Drivers should pay based on miles traveled.

headline: Backsliding in Burma
summary: The constitution could be a winning issue for the opposition.

headline: How Not to Help Black Americans
summary: Failed poverty programs have tried to do what blacks can only do for themselves.

headline: China's Beleaguered Lawyers
summary: Pu Zhiqiang is the latest victim of a lawless regime.

headline: BP Wins Pentagon Supply Deal
summary: BP won a $43 million natural-gas supply contract from the Pentagon, the company's first new Defense Department energy contract since sanctions were lifted after the Deepwater Horizon disaster.

headline: Jordan Releases Jihadist Spiritual Leader
summary: Jordanian officials released the spiritual mentor of a former top al Qaeda leader, prompting some jihadists to suggest he would help unify the movement's factions in Syria and Iraq.

headline: Sterling Continues to Strengthen
summary: Investors pushed the British pound above $1.70 for the first time in nearly five years, betting the BOE will make a pre-emptive strike against inflation by raising interest rates.

headline: Smokers Draw on Apps to Quit
summary: Smokers struggling to quit are getting help from a new wave of products like wireless lighters that track activity, e-cigarettes that measure nicotine intake and apps that test the breath for carbon-monoxide levels.

headline: Supreme Speech Victory
summary: A rebuke to politicians who don't want to be criticized.

headline: Clinton on Keystone
summary: The Democratic nominee in waiting can't tell you what she thinks.

headline: YouTube Superstar Earns Millions Playing Games
summary: Videogame reviewer Felix Kjellberg, aka PewDiePie, is by far YouTube's biggest draw, having built a base of 27 million subscribers. His loud, comic and cuss-filled videos bring in $4 million annually in ad revenue.

headline: New Heart-Valve Procedure Sparks Doctors' Concern
summary: Doctors are grappling with how to manage the use of a new, less-invasive heart-valve procedure that is in high demand from patients, but is relatively unproven for many patients.

headline: 'Hey, Lettuce Hands!' and Other Brazilian Lingo
summary: If World Cup watchers hear Brazilian fans hollering about giving out "chocolate," they shouldn't get their hopes up for dessert: It probably just means that Brazil is pummeling its opponent.

headline: Effort to Reduce Ear Surgeries for Small Children
summary: Ear tubes are frequently done on young children under anesthesia to fix recurrent ear infections. Some doctors think too many of these surgeries are performed unnecessarily and opt for a watchful waiting approach.

headline: GM Recalls 3.4 Million More Cars
summary: General Motors pushed its repair-cost estimate for auto recalls this year to $2 billion as it disclosed plans to replace potentially faulty ignition keys on 3.37 million older model cars in North America.

headline: Fiscal Panel Advises Tough 2015 Budget for Ireland
summary: The worst of Ireland's debt crisis has passed, but the country's two-party coalition should implement plans for a tough 2015 austerity budget, the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council says in a new report.

headline: Germany Dismantles Portugal
summary: Germany routed Portugal with three first-half goals on the way to a 4-0 victory in the opening game of Group G.

headline: Families Vent Pain and Anger Over Risky Uterine Procedure
summary: Hundreds of people nationwide are starting to make their medical experiences public in an unusual debate about whether an approved surgical device should be banned.

headline: Car Dealers Get Flaw Alerts, Why Not Drivers?
summary: Auto makers report flaws and fixes to dealers in Technical Service Bulletins, but watchdogs say the U.S. auto safety regulator uses a technicality to shield them from the public.

headline: Vince Young: NFL's Most Successful Draft Bust
summary: The next time an NFL coach talks about the supreme importance of winning, you might wonder why Vince Young is no longer in the league.

headline: Firms Cash In on Tax-Credit Arms Race
summary: U.S. states are digging deeper into their pockets, offering businesses rich tax credits on everything from brewing beer to renovating buildings, in an effort to spur economic growth and create jobs.

headline: Showdown for Controversial Surgical Tool
summary: Proponents of a surgical tool used for a common uterine procedure argue the device's benefits make it too important to take off the market. But opponents say the tool's cancer-spreading risks make it too dangerous.

headline: A Festival of Contrasts
summary: The pianist Jeremy Denk kept things fresh but familiar as director of the Ojai Music Festival this year.

headline: Challenge to False-Speech Ban Is Revived
summary: The Supreme Court revived a challenge to an Ohio law that criminalizes false political speech, ruling that an activist group need not be punished before it can challenge the measure on First Amendment grounds.

headline: Army Probes Bergdahl Disappearance
summary: The U.S. Army officially launched an investigation into the disappearance and capture of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the 28-year-old American soldier at the center of a controversial prisoner exchange with the Taliban.

headline: Library's Rose Main Reading Room Closed for Six Months
summary: The New York Public Library's Rose Main Reading Room will remain closed for the next six months for inspection and repairs after a plaster rosette fell from its ceiling, library officials said Monday.

headline: Eerie Visions of a Caped Crusader
summary: The Criterion Collection releases French filmmaker Georges Franju's 'Judex' on DVD.

headline: A Modern Takes on Modernity
summary: At this year's International Architecture Exhibition, the focus was on the 'Fundamentals.'

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Paradigm Settles With SEC in Whistleblower Case
summary: The SEC charged a company with retaliating against an employee who blew the whistle on alleged misconduct, a first under the agency's new authority to bring such cases.

headline: Pet-Insurance Provider Trupanion Plans IPO
summary: Pet-insurance provider Trupanion is planning an initial public offering on the NYSE to raise up to $75 million.

headline: AmEx Revs Up Pursuit of the Masses
summary: American Express is courting consumers with a card it pitches as an alternative to checking accounts for people who don't use banks or want a cheaper option.

headline: Jeb Bush Charts Tricky Course on Education
summary: Jeb Bush's embrace of the Common Core educational standards puts him increasingly at odds with conservative activists and other potential Republican presidential contenders.

headline: Congress Turns a Spotlight on Markets
summary: A Senate subcommittee Tuesday begins questioning exchange executives about high-speed computer trading and whether certain aspects of the market have damaged investor confidence.

headline: Accounting Changes Proposed for State, City Retiree-Benefit Plans
summary: States and cities could be forced to report more than $500 billion in additional liabilities for retiree benefits under new accounting rules proposed Monday.

headline: Amira Shares Rise on Strong Sales and Earnings Growth
summary: Amira Nature Foods, a Dubai-based Basmati rice company, posted strong sales and earnings growth in its fiscal fourth quarter, and projected that fiscal 2015 revenue and adjusted Ebitda would rise more than 20%.

headline: Williams to Offer $3 Billion of Stock in Shale Deal
summary: Williams Cos. plans to offer $3 billion in shares as part of its nearly $6 billion ownership expansion in Access Midstream Partners LP, which would give the natural-gas pipeline company a larger presence in areas with growing energy output from shale formations.

headline: Israel Arrests Hamas Leaders in West Bank
summary: Israeli leader talks to Palestinian leader as crisis over kidnapped Israeli teens continued into fifth day.

headline: Met Opera General Manager Earned $1.8 Million in 2012
summary: The general manager, Peter Gelb, has proposed a 16% pay cut for union members in the face of declining ticket sales, a dwindling endowment and growing expenses.

headline: Law Barring Straw' Gun Buys Upheld
summary: The Supreme Court ruled 5-4 Monday a federal law banning the purchase of firearms on behalf of others applies to transactions where the actual buyer could have legally acquired the weapon.

headline: Stocks End Little-Changed
summary: Stocks ended little-changed Monday, as investors weighed the turmoil in Iraq against positive manufacturing data and a burst of corporate deal-making.

headline: Korn/Ferry Profit Rises
summary: Executive recruiter Korn/Ferry International said its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings surged on stronger-than-expected fee revenue.

headline: Dollar Slips on FOMC Risk, Iraq Concerns
summary: Investors unloaded dollars for safe-haven assets Monday ahead of the upcoming meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee and in response to the advance of Sunni militants in Iraq.

headline: U.S. Charges Suspected Activist Hacker

headline: Finra Reviews FireEye Trading Activity Ahead of Mandiant Acquisition
summary: Finra is reviewing trading in computer-security firm FireEye.'s shares ahead of its $1 billion January acquisition of Mandian, another cybersecurity company known for investigating high-profile data breaches.

headline: Level 3 to Buy TW Telecom
summary: Level 3 Communications agreed to buy TW Telecom for about $5.7 billion in cash and stock, a deal that would expand the metropolitan footprint of the long-haul Internet carrier.

headline: IKEA Fan Site to Stop Selling Ads
summary: A popular IKEA fan website devoted to customizing the company's products has agreed to stop selling advertising on the site after the Swedish furniture giant threatened legal action, the website's founder said.

headline: Judge Won't Dismiss Indictments In Malcolm Smith Case
summary: A federal court judge declared a mistrial Monday in New York state Sen. Malcolm Smith's federal corruption and bribery case.

headline: Fed's Plans Hang in Household Balance Sheets
summary: The Fed has lots of positive economic figures to chew on as it meets. But households may not yet be strong enough to digest higher rates.

headline: Astra's CEO Sets New Goals After Fighting Off Pfizer
summary: AstraZeneca Chief Executive Pascal Soriot is looking at ways to boost the U.K. drug maker's share price after fighting off Pfizer, including forming cancer-treatment partnerships with rivals and making its own acquisitions.

headline: Ireland's Regulatory 'Resource Curse'
summary: A rulebook full of loopholes, and tax-optimization by Apple and others, do not help the economy long-term.

headline: Non-Muslims Targeted in Kenya Attack
summary: The gunmen who raided a town along Kenya's popular Indian Ocean coast, killing 48 people, shouted "God is great!" and in some cases asked men to recite Quranic verses before shooting those who couldn't, residents said on Monday.

headline: Treasury Bond Prices Carve Out Small Gains
summary: Treasury bond prices carved out small gains on Monday as growing tensions in Iraq boosted the allure of the U.S. government debt market as a safe haven.

headline: Brent Crude Rises as Violence in Iraq Continues
summary: U.S. and global oil prices diverged Monday as investors remained focused on the possible repercussions of instability in Iraq.

headline: China Initiative Expected to Give London Advantage in Yuan Trading
summary: Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang, visiting the U.K., is expected to confirm China Construction Bank as London's first renminbi, or yuan, clearing bank.

headline: The World's Smartest Surfers
summary: Forget the popular image of surfers as burrito-eating, slang-speaking, sun-bleached stoners: The surf team at the University of California, San Diego studies fields such as physics and biochemistry—and they have won six national titles.

headline: Capital Journal: Opportunities for Obama Amid Iraq's Crisis
summary: Even with Sunni extremists swallowing up territory and threatening the American-installed government in Iraq, the looming disaster actually gives the Obama administration real leverage, if it only chooses to use it.

headline: Yet More Income Redistribution?
summary: It's only the higher-income families that will have to pay the actual premiums which are escalating to $15,000 or more.

headline: Making Sure the Ball Is Never Out of Sight
summary: In addition to using new camera angles such as "north-south" orientation, producers can enlarge the hockey puck by using telephoto lenses like the center-field camera in baseball.

headline: If Blackouts Hit the Golden State
summary: In his June 10 letter on New Carbon Standards, Randolph Scheffel speculates about the consequences of losses of power because of new regulations by the EPA.

headline: IEX Group Hires Former Top SEC Official Ramsay
summary: The high-profile addition speaks to mounting concerns among regulators and law-enforcement officials about whether some fast-moving traders have unfair advantages.

headline: Buying an Annuity Holds Certain Risks
summary: Describing the purchase of an annuity as handing over a lump sum to an insurer is hardly commensurate with the risk involved in the transaction.

headline: Tony Gwynn Dies at 54
summary: Baseball legend Tony Gwynn has died after a lengthy battle with cancer.  The Hall of Fame right fielder spent the entirety of his 20-year career with the San Diego Padres.

headline: White House: U.S. Won't Coordinate With Iran
summary: The U.S. won't take coordinated military action with Iran as part of a broader effort to stem escalating violence in Iraq, the White House said on Monday.

headline: U.K.'s Hague Discussed Iraq With Iranian Counterpart
summary: U.K. Foreign Secretary William Hague discussed the situation in Iraq with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad-Javad Zarif over the weekend.

headline: Housing Numbers Reflect Shift in American Dream
summary: When investors parse economic data to see how close the U.S. economy is to getting "back to normal," they must redefine normal.

headline: Ford Paid Workers the Median Rate
summary: Ford's tremendous growth coincided with an America that became more productive and therefore created more wealth, some of which could be used to buy cars.

headline: Mediobanca, Intesa, Generali to Withdraw From Telco
summary: Mediobanca, Intesa Sanpaolo and Assicurazioni Generali plan to withdraw from Telco, which has a 22.4% stake in Telecom Italia, paving the way for Spain's Telefónica to become the single largest shareholder in the Italian telecom giant.

headline: Is 'E Pluribus Unum' Destined to Be a Quaint Relic?
summary: Compromise is possible only if you believe that the members of the opposite side are cut from the same moral cloth as yourself.

headline: Immigration Reform Proposals Treat Only Symptoms
summary: Treating the symptoms through some sort of step-by-step approach that results in eventual citizenship sends the wrong message.

summary: The International Monetary Fund cut its forecast for U.S. economic growth this year by 0.8 percentage points to 2% but said a meaningful economic rebound is nonetheless under way.

headline: Iranian Quds Force Soldier Killed in Iraq Fighting Sunni Extremists
summary: An Iranian soldier from Quds Force, the elite overseas branch of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps, was killed in Iraq fighting Sunni extremists, reported news agencies affiliated with Iran's government Monday.

headline: Gold Climbs on Worries Over Iraq
summary: Gold prices carved out a modest gain Monday as worries about escalating violence in Iraq were tempered by stronger U.S. equities.

headline: Boeing's 787-9 Dreamliner Approved by Regulators
summary: Boeing said U.S. and European regulators approved its larger 787 Dreamliner model for commercial service.

headline: SanDisk and Fusion-io: Flash Sale
summary: SanDisk may be picking up Fusion-io on the cheap, but that doesn't mean a better deal may be had.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Internet Free-Speech Case
summary: The Supreme Court agreed to take up a free-speech case that examines what it means to threaten someone in the Internet age.

headline: Pakistani Casualties in Taliban Fight
summary: Pakistan's military Monday suffered the first military casualties in its much-anticipated operation to clear out the Taliban stronghold of North Waziristan, as Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif declared that the offensive will go on no matter the cost.

headline: Quebec Seeks C$409 Million From Defunct Railway
summary: The Quebec government added itself to a group of creditors seeking damages from the insolvent railroad behind the July 2013 derailment in Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, that killed 47.

headline: Judge Rules for Macy's in Legal Spat
summary: Penney interfered with a merchandising pact between Macy's and Martha Stewart, a New York judged ruled Monday, the latest twist in a long-running dispute between the retailers over the homemaking maven.

headline: 7-Eleven to Open Store in Dubai
summary: 7-Eleven Inc. has reached a deal with Seven Emirates Investment LLC to enter the Middle East market, the company said Monday.

headline: Bank of America Will Screen for Payday Lenders
summary: Bank of America has agreed to use a software database developed by New York's top financial regulator to flag payday lenders that could be violating state laws.

headline: Hungary Court Says Banks Should Be More Transparent With Forex Loans
summary: Hungary's top court ruled that exposing retail customers to foreign-exchange risk wasn't unfair,  but banks should have offered sufficient information about the risk when selling foreign-currency loans.

headline: Google Faces Fresh Antitrust Woes
summary: Google is facing fresh accusations of anticompetitive behavior in Europe over its Android operating system for mobile phones.

headline: Icelandair Cancels Flights as Mechanics Strike
summary: A strike by mechanics working for Icelandair was expected to affect travel plans for 12,000 people Monday as the airline canceled 65 flights

headline: Medtronic's Taxing Trip Overseas
summary: Medtronic's $43 billion deal to buy Irish-domiciled Covidien may have strategic appeal. But the U.S. company is paying a high price for tax flexibility.

headline: The Polarization of Colombia
summary: Santos wins re-election but FARC talks still loom.

headline: Obama's Priorities
summary: With the Arab world in flames, the president complains about the weather.

headline: ING Expects to Raise €1.3 Billion to €1.5 Billion in NN Group IPO
summary: Dutch bank ING Groep NV unveiled pricing details for the initial public offering of its NN Group insurance business, saying it expects to raise €1.3 billion to €1.5 billion ($1.76 billion to $2.04 billion) through the sale of a 26.4% stake in one of Europe's biggest stock market flotations this year.

headline: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala In Talks To Cut Debt Owed by Eike Batista
summary: The biggest investor in Brazilian Eike Batista's holding company is still struggling to reduce its exposure to the troubled industrial group.

headline: Remembering Tony Gwynn
summary: San Diego Padres legend Tony Gwynn died at the age of 54 after a lengthy battle with cancer.

headline: Ukrainian President to Unveil Peace Plan
summary: Ukraine's President said he would unveil a detailed peace plan in the coming days to end fighting with separatists in the east.

headline: Polish Authorities Reject Tape Criminality Claims
summary: Two Polish officials whose leaked conversation roiled the country's ruling elite over the weekend have stayed in their jobs with authorities saying a recording of their exchange provided no evidence of criminal wrongdoing.

headline: Alibaba's Unsettling Book of Revelation
summary: Alibaba's most recent filing ahead of its IPO gave prospective investors more information about its main two marketplaces. But it also showed heavy spending is leading to margin erosion.

headline: Nuance Explores Possible Sale
summary: Speech-recognition software maker Nuance Communications has held discussions with potential suitors regarding a sale of the company, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Europe Shares Fall on Iraq Worries
summary: European shares fell amid concerns over the escalating conflict in Iraq, which continued to boost oil prices.

headline: GTECH in Talks to Buy IGT
summary: GTECH, an Italian lottery company, said it had begun preliminary talks to acquire International Game Technology, a Las Vegas-based gaming company.

headline: China Rejects Call for Construction Freeze in Disputed Seas
summary: China rejected the Philippines' call for a halt to construction projects in disputed areas of the South China Sea, insisting it has the right to build on what it regards as Chinese territory.

headline: India to Retain Tough Tone in Trade Talks
summary: The new leaders in New Delhi will stay tough in trade talks and keep India's retail market closed, but they will also try to attract more foreign investment by lowering barriers to business and clarifying tax law, its trade minister said.

headline: Home Builders' Confidence Index Posts First Gain Since December
summary: A gauge of home-builder confidence rose this month for the first time since December, though it reflected continued concern over weak buyer demand.

headline: Photos: Somali Extremists Attack Kenyan Town
summary: Dozens of Somali extremists wielding automatic weapons attacked a small Kenyan coastal town about 100 kilometers (60 miles) from the Somali border overnight, officials said Monday.

headline: HSBC's U.S. CEO to Retire This Year
summary: HSBC U.S. Chief Executive Irene Dorner, a 32-year HSBC veteran and one of the U.S.'s most senior female bankers, will retire this year and be replaced by Patrick Burke.

headline: Bank of Russia Keeps Rates on Hold
summary: Russia's central bank left interest rates unchanged, but warned it may tighten monetary policy despite a slowdown in growth, as inflation remained elevated.

headline: Obama to Bar Gay Discrimination by Contractors
summary: President Obama plans to sign an executive order barring federal contractors from hiring or firing employees based on their sexual orientation or gender identity, senior administration officials said, in a move that could energize Democratic voters in November's midterm elections.

headline: Less Capital Flows Into China
summary: The flow of capital into China slowed sharply in May, a shift that analysts said reflected a reduction of speculative capital brought into the country as the nation's currency weakens.

headline: Nestlé Seeks to Revitalize Nescafé Brand
summary: Nestlé wants to brew up interest in one of its oldest brands—Nescafé instant coffee.

headline: Brazil Moves to Attract Smaller Companies to Capital Markets
summary: Government will waive the 15% capital-gains tax on the trading of shares in companies with revenue of up to the equivalent of $224 million.

headline: The Team With Four Captains
summary: As it opens its 2014 World Cup campaign against Ghana on Monday, the U.S. men's national soccer team will take the field with a highly unusual command structure: Any one of four or five different players might lead.

headline: When a Monarch Calls It Quits
summary: A brief history of royal abdication, from Tarquin the Proud in 509 B.C. to Juan Carlos of Spain.

headline: OCBC's Pickle in Bid for Wing Hang Bank
summary: Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp.'s $5 billion deal for Wing Hang Bank is likely to close, but a ploy by investors could force the acquirer to bear additional costs.

headline: Glencore Helped Finance Chad's Acquisition of Chevron Assets
summary: Commodities giant Glencore helped finance Chad's $1.3 billion acquisition of Chevron's oil assets in the African country, according to the Chadian government.

headline: Fraud Accusations Imperil Afghan Vote
summary: Allegations of ballot-stuffing in the presidential election threatened to undermine Afghanistan's first democratic power transfer in its history.
